history.content: I would double check to make sure you can cross two major requirements between Haas and CS. Otherwise, it seems fairly doable. Consider taking  summer classes (CC or at Berkeley) as this might help -- especially as this summer is online so it may be more affordable. I am double majoring and I took my R1B and CS70 over the summer after my freshman year and it probably shaved off a semester for me since i could start taking upper divs that required CS 70 (like 170) sooner. If you can take a Haas lower div requirement over CC i'd recommend that too

children.subject: You might also want to check out the course plan for the M.E.T. program (http://guide.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/degree-programs/electrical-engineering-computer-sciences-business-administration/#planofstudytext). M.E.T. students have one or two requirements removed for them, but the guide my help you out.

I agree with this in that one should consider deeply whether a double major is best, but I think OP's situation is a bit different. There could (there almost certainly is, otherwise it wouldn't be in demand) be some benefits to actually being a declared Haas major when one wants to take Haas courses (like actually getting in the courses). If someone was asking about declaring CS as their double major, they'd almost have to if they wanted to be able to take as many CS UD classes as they can, since non-majors can't even enroll until adjustment period.
A lot of the time, if one wants to take a math class, they just can (assuming prereqs are met). If math was impacted, there would be benefit in double majoring like OP is describing.
Please make sure this is something you really want to do! @4252

I'd argue you can become a PM and Haas classes wouldn't be necessary. My brother majored in CS and took like one business class and said it wasn't that helpful for his job. What helped is that he led some clubs and organized hackathons for a while. PM may require some independent experience-seeking but it may be more worth it to focus ones time on seeking those independent experiences rather than spending time trying to declare Haas. But who knows maybe OP genuinely loves business as a subject! I have friends who are taking Haas classes because they are interested in sustainable business practices, policy, etc. and who knows OP may be a future reformer in silicon valley business practices! But yeah, I agree there are fewer reasons to double major than one initially thinks

What you are saying about PM not needing a business degree is not wrong. I was just giving OP the only example I could think of where one may benefit from both a Haas and CS degree. For example, at the place that I work at now, some of the (associate/rotational)PMs have consulting experience (though it's definitely not required and doesn't guarantee by any means that you'll be a good PM). Since OP is a freshman, it seems to me that they may just want to major in business because their friends and people who look important (to a freshman at least LOL) on Sproul and LinkedIn are majoring it so I was posting that to make sure they think deeply about why they really want to double major in the first place.

In fact, one could argue that it is much better to become a SWE first and then become a PM at L5. In this case, I would argue that it is much better to pursue CS alone, but along the way making sure that you have developed the skills that it takes to be a good PM (many people that actually do become PMs fail to become a good PM because they don't have these skills).

Yea don't worry. I'm not head over heels about the sproul clubs or anything like that, I'm just a fan of business studies and it's a lot easier to take classes if I'm in the major. I fully plan on using my CS skills outside of the classroom for my career but I feel like having business knowledge could help me in my personal life.

I'm know people who did Haas and CS, and am friends with one of them. However, the only reason why you should do this is if you know you want to become a PM. If you want to become a SWE then the Haas degree will be useless.

Declared CS and Haas-- very doable, just check that you can get breadth credit from UGBA core classes. I've had to take 5 classes a semester since sophomore spring, so double-check all of the requirements.

I agree with this. Since your question about OP's proposed schedule was already answered (i.e. its fine), it may be good to chime in for others reading this that double majoring comes at a greater cost than one thinks (money wise its around $20-30k in units and about a year of your time, considering one who doesn't double major, who is willing to take medium semesters and who isn't really interested in classes from a bunch of different departments/learning a language/etc. can easily graduate in 3 years). This is significant, graduating early is smart for a lot of people who really don't want to take those other classes and who want to get industry experience asap. Double majoring forces you into the other option of taking the full 4 years and often longer, and you still don't get to take any of those other misc. courses (unless you want to have around 20 units a semester). Double majoring has a lot of stress involved too, since every major has at those least 1-3 required courses that one isn't really interested in but has to take, and this might just get shoved to your sr. year when you may already be starting to regret doing the double major. 

I am personally double majoring (so don't think i am totally against it) only because my freshman/early sophomore year i found myself often not being able to do my CS homework because I would go to main stacks to do a project and end up just spending the whole time reading books on the topic I'm double majoring it. It got to a point where it was hurting my ability to do CS as much as I could before, and that's when I realized I really wanted to do that other topic and not CS (I am still in CS though, since honestly its kind of a shame to drop a CS major at berkeley, and since its such a good program and there are infinite possibilities for how to apply CS to other fields CS makes kind of an exception, Haas isn't the same way though). Anyway, sorry if it sounds like I'm trying to dissuade you, I am really not, but like Atom said above, I wouldn't be super hasty to do it unless you like highkey like business more than CS or only saw CS as a supplement to something else, or your job/grad school really required your diploma to say Haas on it (i personally can't think of anything like this).

op here, thank you so much for this well thought out response. My situation is fairly unique and I am fairly aware of the sacrifices I must make in order to pull this off. I’m passionate about CS but due to outlying personal circumstances will benefit hugely from a piece of paper with Haas on it. Thanks for the time to send this info and it helps a lot to see the experiences other students have had.

Good luck with everything!! I don't blame you for wanting a piece of paper with Haas on it - it's a great thing to have, and an incredible achievement. Plus, Haas can be a lot of fun sometimes too. :)

Econ 2 will not count as a breadth because it's a Haas requirement! You can also use UGBA 104/101A/101B as CS technical electives if you'd like to take different ugba electives instead. 

As a graduating senior who is doubling in CS/business, I'm honestly not sure it was the right thing to do. I've been disappointed in different ways with both majors/departments, and probably would have been happier doing neither major (not necessarily because of the workload though, more because of the content and people), but that's obviously a very personal choice. That being said, it seems like you have really thought this through - I still didn't know what I wanted to major in at the end of freshman year, so you're way ahead! Like someone said above, taking a business/breadth class or two online this summer would be a great way to ease your future workload if you don't have plans already.

One other point I would bring up is: if you know you want to be a software engineer in the end, I don't think the business major will do that much for you - you're better off just taking the UGBA electives that really interest you and focusing on learning+enjoying CS and doing research, rather than just doing the bare minimum in CS. 

hope this helped!

history.content: Hi, I'm a current freshman and I wanted to see if it was even possible to major in cs and get the degree from haas and this is what I came up with. Is there any advice? Thank you so much. High school breaths and requirements achieved: Entry level writing American History American Institutions Foreign Language Freshman Fall CS 61A (Quant reasoning) Math 1A French R1A  Nutrisci 10 (Biological Breath) Freshman Spring (I am here right now) Econ 2 (Social breath) Math 1B His 171c (History breath) CS 61B Soph Fall (15 units) EE 16A CS 70 UGBA 10 R1B Soph Spring (16 units) CS 70 EE 16B Stat 20 Theatre AC (AC plus art) Junior Fall (13 units) CS 188 CS 61C (physical UGBA 100 UGBA 101A Junior Spring CS 162 UGBA 180 (CS technical elective ) UGBA 105 UGBA 107 (Philosophy breath) Senior Fall CS 161 UGBA 101B UGBA 102A UGBA 104 UGBA 118 (international breath, CS technical elective) Senior Spring CS 168 UGBA 102B UGBA 103 UGBA 106 UGBA 133 I understand this is fairly ambitious and I can kinda tell I am missing out on a lot of great CS classes here in order to try and double major. Does anyone have any advice based on looking at this? Any and all feedback is welcomed even if you just wish to roast me for this. Thank you so much.
history.subject: 4 year plan advice (LSCS and Haas)
